chdLesions.hemodynamics: Right-to-left shunt via VSD with RV outflow obstruction
chdLesions.presentation: Tet spells (hypercyanotic episodes), squatting preference, boot-shaped heart on CXR
chdLesions.murmur: Harsh systolic ejection murmur at LUSB, decreases during tet spell
chdLesions.management: Knee-to-chest positioning for tet spells; propranolol for spells; surgical repair by 3-6 months
chdLesions.associations: DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion), CHARGE, Down syndrome

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Aorta arises from RV, pulmonary artery from LV; incompatible with life without mixing
chdLesions.presentation: Severe cyanosis at day 1-3 of life, no improvement with O2, single loud S2, egg-on-string CXR
chdLesions.murmur: Often no murmur early; may have systolic ejection murmur
chdLesions.management: PGE1 to keep ductus arteriosus open; balloon atrial septostomy (Rashkind procedure); definitive: arterial switch (Jatene)
chdLesions.associations: Maternal diabetes, pregestational diabetes more than gestational

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Underdevelopment of LV, mitral/aortic valve atresia; RV-dependent systemic circulation
chdLesions.presentation: Severe cyanosis and shock on day 1-2 of life; soft or silent S2; no femoral pulses
chdLesions.murmur: Variable; may have continuous PDA murmur
chdLesions.management: PGE1 emergently; staged surgical repair (Norwood, Glenn, Fontan) or cardiac transplantation
chdLesions.associations: Maternal phenylketonuria (PKU), Down syndrome, Noonan syndrome

chdLesions.hemodynamics: All pulmonary veins drain to systemic venous system; mixing occurs at ASD/PFO
chdLesions.presentation: Cyanosis, may present with pulmonary edema (if obstructed TAPVR), generalized edema, failure to thrive
chdLesions.murmur: Wide fixed split S2; may have ejection systolic murmur
chdLesions.management: Surgical repair; if obstructed or unstable → PGE1 to keep PDA open and improve mixing
chdLesions.associations: Heterotaxy syndromes (situs inversus), asplenia/polysplenia

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Absent tricuspid valve; requires ASD/PFO and PDA for survival
chdLesions.presentation: Cyanosis (day 1-2 life), single loud S2, no murmur or quiet systolic murmur
chdLesions.murmur: Quiet or absent; no systolic murmur from tricuspid regurgitation
chdLesions.management: PGE1; staged surgical repair (Blalock-Taussig shunt → Glenn → Fontan)
chdLesions.associations: Down syndrome, DiGeorge syndrome

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Single arterial trunk overrides VSD, supplies systemic, pulmonary, and coronary circulation
chdLesions.presentation: Mild cyanosis, bounding pulses (truncal valve regurgitation), wide pulse pressure, heart failure
chdLesions.murmur: Loud systolic ejection murmur at LUSB; truncal regurgitation (diastolic murmur)
chdLesions.management: Surgical repair (separate pulmonary arteries from trunk); PGE1 if PDA closure threatens pulmonary flow
chdLesions.associations: DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion), increased in infants of diabetic mothers

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Left-to-right shunt; size determines hemodynamic significance
chdLesions.presentation: Varies: small = asymptomatic; large = failure to thrive, cardiomegaly, pulmonary edema
chdLesions.murmur: Holosystolic murmur at LLSB (small VSDs); large VSDs may have softer murmur due to small pressure gradient
chdLesions.management: Small VSDs: observation (many close spontaneously); large VSDs: diuretics + ACE inhibitors; surgical closure if refractory heart failure
chdLesions.associations: Down syndrome, DiGeorge syndrome, CHARGE, fetal alcohol syndrome

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Left-to-right atrial shunt; increased pulmonary blood flow
chdLesions.presentation: Often asymptomatic in childhood; may have dyspnea on exertion, recurrent respiratory infections
chdLesions.murmur: Wide fixed split S2 (even with expiration); soft systolic ejection murmur at LUSB from increased RV output
chdLesions.management: Observation in childhood; percutaneous or surgical closure if indicated (shunt ratio >1.5:1 or symptomatic)
chdLesions.associations: Ostium secundum ASD (70%), ostium primum ASD (15%), sinus venosus ASD (15%), Holt-Oram syndrome

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Left-to-right shunt from aorta to pulmonary artery; increased pulmonary blood flow
chdLesions.presentation: Premature infants: often asymptomatic; term infants: bounding pulses, wide pulse pressure, hyperactive precordium
chdLesions.murmur: Continuous 'machine-like' murmur throughout systole and diastole, best at LUSB
chdLesions.management: Premature: indomethacin/ibuprofen or acetaminophen to close PDA; if fails → surgical ligation. In ductal-dependent lesions: PGE1 to keep open
chdLesions.associations: Prematurity, maternal rubella infection, maternal NSAIDs in third trimester

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Narrowing of aorta, typically just distal to left subclavian artery
chdLesions.presentation: Hypertension in upper extremities, weak/delayed lower extremity pulses, narrow pulse in legs, rib notching on CXR
chdLesions.murmur: Systolic ejection murmur at left infraclavular region; continuous murmur from collateral circulation
chdLesions.management: Surgical repair or balloon angioplasty/stenting; screen for associated anomalies (bicuspid aortic valve, Turner syndrome)
chdLesions.associations: Turner syndrome (15-20%), bicuspid aortic valve, hypoplastic left heart, mitral valve abnormalities

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Left ventricular outflow obstruction; pressure overload → LVH
chdLesions.presentation: Often asymptomatic; severe AS: angina, syncope, dyspnea, sudden cardiac death with exertion
chdLesions.murmur: Systolic ejection murmur at RUSB with ejection click (unless valve completely calcified)
chdLesions.management: Serial monitoring with echo; beta-blockers for symptom relief; valve replacement when symptomatic or gradient >60 mmHg
chdLesions.associations: Bicuspid aortic valve (most common), rheumatic heart disease, supravalvular AS (Williams syndrome, hypercalcemia)

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Right ventricular outflow obstruction; pressure overload → RVH
chdLesions.presentation: Often asymptomatic; severe PS: dyspnea, syncope, RVH, prominent RV heave
chdLesions.murmur: Systolic ejection murmur at LUSB with ejection click; murmur increases with inspiration (Carvallo sign)
chdLesions.management: Mild PS (<30 mmHg): observation; moderate-severe PS: balloon valvuloplasty
chdLesions.associations: Noonan syndrome, Williams syndrome, congenital rubella, Klinefelter syndrome

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Tricuspid valve displaced downward into RV; tricuspid regurgitation, right atrial enlargement
chdLesions.presentation: Cyanosis (variable), dyspnea, arrhythmias (WPW syndrome in 5-10%), right heart failure
buzzwords: right axis deviation with tall P waves
chdLesions.murmur: S3 or S4 (atrial gallop), tricuspid regurgitation murmur (holosystolic at LLSB), may have opening snap
chdLesions.management: Symptomatic: diuretics, digoxin; severe cases: surgical repair or valve replacement; manage WPW if present
chdLesions.associations: Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW), maternal lithium exposure, Down syndrome

chdLesions.lesion: Atrioventricular Canal Defect (AV Canal/Endocardial Cushion Defect)
chdLesions.hemodynamics: Ostium primum ASD, inlet VSD, cleft mitral/tricuspid valve; left-to-right shunting
chdLesions.presentation: Holosystolic murmur, wide fixed split S2, signs of left-to-right shunt, early heart failure
buzzwords: Down syndrome (50% of complete AV canal)
chdLesions.murmur: Holosystolic murmur (mitral regurgitation), widely split S2, left-sided S3
chdLesions.management: Surgical repair (usually within first year of life to prevent Eisenmenger syndrome)
chdLesions.associations: Down syndrome (50%), trisomy 18, trisomy 13, Marfan syndrome

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Both aorta and pulmonary artery arise from RV; mixing via ASD or VSD
chdLesions.presentation: Cyanosis, single loud S2, symptoms depend on associated defects (VSD, ASD)
chdLesions.murmur: Variable; depends on associated defects
chdLesions.management: Surgical repair (depends on anatomy; may include Rastelli procedure)
chdLesions.associations: DiGeorge syndrome, Down syndrome, heterotaxy

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Uncorrected left-to-right shunt → pulmonary vascular disease → reversal to right-to-left shunt
chdLesions.presentation: Progressive cyanosis, dyspnea, syncope, right heart failure; irreversible without heart-lung transplant
chdLesions.murmur: Single loud S2, early diastolic PR murmur (pulmonary regurgitation), no holosystolic murmur if shunt reversed
chdLesions.management: Oxygen, diuretics, digoxin; avoid pregnancy; heart-lung transplantation only definitive treatment
chdLesions.associations: Uncorrected large VSD/ASD/PDA, longstanding left-to-right shunt

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Patent foramen ovale; usually hemodynamically insignificant
chdLesions.presentation: Asymptomatic; right-to-left shunting only with increased right atrial pressure (Valsalva)
chdLesions.murmur: Usually no murmur; if significant shunt, may have murmur from pulmonary flow
chdLesions.management: Usually no treatment; consider closure if paradoxical embolism, recurrent strokes, or migraine with aura
chdLesions.associations: Normal variant (25-30% of population), paradoxical embolism, cryptogenic stroke

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Complete discontinuity of aortic arch; RV-dependent systemic circulation via PDA
chdLesions.presentation: Cyanosis, shock, severe hypertension in upper extremities, absent lower body pulses, no improvement with O2
chdLesions.murmur: Variable; continuous murmur from PDA
chdLesions.management: PGE1 emergently to maintain PDA; surgical repair (usually within first week of life)
chdLesions.associations: DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion), CHARGE, thymoma

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Narrowing above aortic valve due to elastin gene (ELN) deletion
chdLesions.presentation: Systolic ejection murmur, facial dysmorphism (elfin features), developmental delay, hypercalcemia
chdLesions.murmur: Systolic ejection murmur at RUSB; may be louder in aorta than pulmonary artery
chdLesions.management: Avoid excess vitamin D and calcium; beta-blockers for hypertension; surgical repair if severe obstruction
chdLesions.associations: Williams syndrome (deletion 7q11.23), sporadic SVAS, heterozygous familial SVAS

chdLesions.hemodynamics: Absent pulmonary valve; right ventricle-dependent pulmonary circulation via PDA
chdLesions.presentation: Severe cyanosis from day 1 of life, single loud S2, RVH, no improvement with supplemental oxygen
chdLesions.murmur: Continuous PDA murmur; no valve sound from missing pulmonary valve
chdLesions.management: PGE1 to keep ductus arteriosus open; staged surgical repair (Blalock-Taussig shunt)
chdLesions.associations: DiGeorge syndrome, Down syndrome, maternal diabetes

murmurQuiz.scenario: 2-year-old with failure to thrive and diaphoresis during feeding. Harsh holosystolic murmur loudest at LLSB. Pansystolic thrill palpable. CXR shows cardiomegaly with increased pulmonary vascular markings.

parts.questionPrompt: What murmur is this?
parts.answer: Holosystolic murmur of VSD
parts.explanation: VSD produces a harsh holosystolic (pansystolic) murmur at the LLSB from LV→RV shunting. The pressure gradient is constant throughout systole. A palpable thrill indicates hemodynamic significance.

parts.questionPrompt: Why would a SMALLER VSD produce a LOUDER murmur?
parts.answer: Higher pressure gradient across the small defect = higher velocity jet = more turbulence
distractors: Smaller defects are closer to the chest wall
Small VSDs cause more pulmonary hypertension
Restrictive VSDs have associated valve abnormalities
parts.explanation: Small restrictive VSDs maintain a high LV-to-RV pressure gradient → high velocity jet through a small hole = loud turbulence. Large VSDs equalize pressures → lower gradient → SOFTER murmur but WORSE hemodynamics. This is a classic shelf pearl!

parts.questionPrompt: This child fails medical therapy (diuretics, ACE-I). What is the definitive management?
parts.answer: Surgical VSD closure (patch repair)
distractors: Continued medical management and wait for spontaneous closure
parts.explanation: Large VSDs failing medical therapy need surgical patch closure, ideally before irreversible pulmonary vascular disease (by 6-12 months of age). Small VSDs may close spontaneously. Indomethacin is for PDA, not VSD.

murmurQuiz.scenario: Premature neonate in NICU with worsening respiratory status. Continuous 'machine-like' murmur at left infraclavicular area. Bounding pulses with wide pulse pressure. Hyperactive precordium.

parts.questionPrompt: What murmur is this?
parts.answer: Continuous machinery murmur of PDA
parts.explanation: The continuous 'machinery' murmur is pathognomonic for PDA. Aortic pressure exceeds PA pressure throughout the cardiac cycle → continuous shunting. Bounding pulses and wide pulse pressure from diastolic runoff into PA.

parts.questionPrompt: What is the first-line pharmacologic treatment?
parts.answer: Indomethacin (or ibuprofen) — inhibits prostaglandin synthesis
parts.explanation: NSAIDs (indomethacin or ibuprofen) inhibit prostaglandin synthesis → promote ductal closure. PGE1 does the OPPOSITE — keeps PDA open (used in ductal-dependent lesions). Surgical ligation is reserved for NSAID failure.

parts.questionPrompt: What lab must be monitored during indomethacin therapy?
parts.answer: Renal function (BUN/Creatinine) — indomethacin is nephrotoxic
parts.explanation: Indomethacin causes renal vasoconstriction → decreased GFR → oliguria and elevated creatinine. Monitor BUN/Cr, urine output, and electrolytes. Contraindicated if Cr >1.8, active bleeding, or NEC.

murmurQuiz.scenario: 4-year-old girl with dyspnea on exertion. Wide FIXED split S2 that does not vary with respiration. Soft systolic ejection murmur at LUSB. Mid-diastolic rumble at LLSB.

parts.questionPrompt: What murmur is this?
parts.answer: Systolic ejection murmur of ASD (relative pulmonic flow murmur)
parts.explanation: The murmur of ASD is from increased flow across the pulmonic valve (relative PS), NOT from blood crossing the septum. The hallmark is FIXED split S2 — RV volume is constantly elevated regardless of respiration.

parts.questionPrompt: What does the FIXED split S2 indicate?
parts.answer: Constant RV volume overload delays pulmonic valve closure regardless of respiratory phase
distractors: Aortic stenosis causing early aortic valve closure
parts.explanation: Normally, S2 splitting increases with inspiration (more RV filling → delayed P2). In ASD, the RV is ALWAYS volume-overloaded from left-to-right shunt → P2 is ALWAYS delayed → fixed splitting. This is the single most important finding for ASD on the shelf exam.

murmurQuiz.scenario: 5-year-old with crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur at RUSB. Ejection click early in systole. Murmur radiates to carotids. Narrow pulse pressure.

parts.questionPrompt: What murmur is this?
parts.answer: Crescendo-decrescendo (ejection) murmur of Aortic Stenosis
parts.explanation: AS produces a diamond-shaped systolic ejection murmur at the RUSB. Radiation to carotids distinguishes it from PS. The ejection click occurs from opening of a stenotic but pliable valve. Narrow pulse pressure reflects reduced stroke volume.

parts.questionPrompt: This child has elfin facies, friendly personality, and hypercalcemia. What syndrome?
parts.answer: Williams syndrome (supravalvular AS)
parts.explanation: Williams syndrome (7q11.23 deletion) causes supravalvular AS. Features: elfin facies, cocktail party personality, intellectual disability, hypercalcemia. Noonan = PS. Turner = CoA/bicuspid AV. DiGeorge = conotruncal defects.

parts.questionPrompt: What is the most common cause of AS in children?
parts.answer: Bicuspid aortic valve
parts.explanation: Bicuspid aortic valve (BAV) is the most common cause of AS in children and young adults, present in ~1-2% of the population. Rheumatic AS is more common in developing countries. Calcific degeneration causes AS in elderly adults.

murmurQuiz.scenario: Newborn with systolic ejection murmur at LUSB. Ejection click present. Murmur intensity INCREASES with inspiration. RV heave noted, no cyanosis.

parts.questionPrompt: What murmur is this?
parts.answer: Systolic ejection murmur of Pulmonic Stenosis
parts.explanation: PS produces a systolic ejection murmur at the LUSB. KEY: it INCREASES with inspiration (more blood returns to RV → louder). This is part of the Carvallo sign. AS is at RUSB and radiates to carotids.

parts.questionPrompt: This child has short stature, webbed neck, and wide-spaced nipples. What syndrome?
parts.answer: Noonan syndrome
parts.explanation: PS is the hallmark cardiac lesion of Noonan syndrome. Features: short stature, webbed neck, wide-spaced nipples, pectus, cryptorchidism. Affects all genders (autosomal dominant). Turner (45,X) = females only with CoA/bicuspid AV.

parts.questionPrompt: Moderate-to-severe PS is confirmed. What is the treatment?
parts.answer: Balloon valvuloplasty (percutaneous)
parts.explanation: Balloon valvuloplasty is the treatment of choice for moderate-severe PS with excellent outcomes. Mild PS can be observed. Surgical valvotomy is reserved for dysplastic valves (common in Noonan) that don't respond to balloon valvuloplasty.

murmurQuiz.scenario: 3-year-old with musical/vibratory quality systolic murmur at LLSB. Grade 2/6, louder when supine, softer when standing. No diastolic component. Normal S1, S2. Asymptomatic, normal growth.

parts.questionPrompt: What murmur is this?
parts.answer: Still's murmur (innocent vibratory murmur)
parts.explanation: Still's murmur is the most common innocent murmur in children (ages 2-7). Hallmark: musical/vibratory quality. Louder supine, softer standing. Disappears with Valsalva. No diastolic component, no clicks.

parts.questionPrompt: Parents are anxious. What workup is indicated?
parts.answer: No workup needed — reassurance only
parts.explanation: Innocent murmurs with all reassuring features need NO workup. Refer for echo when: diastolic murmur, harsh quality, symptoms (syncope, cyanosis, FTT), abnormal S2, fixed splitting, or loud (≥3/6) murmur.

murmurQuiz.scenario: Teenage girl with mid-systolic click followed by late systolic murmur at apex. Click and murmur move EARLIER with Valsalva and standing. Click moves LATER with squatting. Tall, thin habitus.

parts.questionPrompt: What murmur is this?
parts.answer: Mid-systolic click and late systolic murmur of MVP
parts.explanation: MVP produces a mid-systolic click from sudden tensing of chordae, followed by late systolic MR murmur. Valsalva/standing → less preload → smaller LV → earlier prolapse → click moves EARLIER. Squatting → more preload → later prolapse.

parts.questionPrompt: This patient has arachnodactyly, pectus excavatum, and upward lens subluxation. What syndrome?
parts.answer: Marfan syndrome
parts.explanation: MVP is strongly associated with Marfan syndrome (FBN1 mutation). Features: tall stature, arm span > height, arachnodactyly, pectus, upward lens subluxation, aortic root dilation, and MVP. Homocystinuria has DOWNward lens subluxation.

murmurQuiz.scenario: 12-year-old athlete with systolic murmur at Erb's point (LLSB). Murmur INCREASES with Valsalva and standing. DECREASES with squatting and leg elevation. ECG shows deep Q waves and LVH.

parts.questionPrompt: What murmur is this?
parts.answer: Crescendo-decrescendo murmur of HOCM (dynamic LVOT obstruction)
parts.explanation: HOCM = dynamic LVOT obstruction. Valsalva/standing DECREASE preload → smaller LV → septum closer to mitral valve → MORE obstruction → LOUDER. Squatting INCREASES preload → LESS obstruction → SOFTER. This is OPPOSITE to most other murmurs.

parts.questionPrompt: This athlete's father died suddenly at age 35. Can the patient continue competitive sports?
parts.answer: No — disqualification from competitive sports + consider ICD
parts.explanation: HOCM is the #1 cause of sudden cardiac death in young athletes. Competitive sports are CONTRAINDICATED. Family history of SCD is a high-risk feature warranting ICD. Beta-blockers help symptoms but do NOT prevent SCD.

parts.questionPrompt: Which medications should be AVOIDED in HOCM?
parts.answer: Diuretics and vasodilators (decrease preload → worsen obstruction)
parts.explanation: Diuretics and vasodilators DECREASE preload/afterload → smaller LV cavity → MORE obstruction → worse symptoms. Beta-blockers (slow HR, increase filling time) and verapamil are used to TREAT HOCM. Disopyramide is a negative inotrope that reduces obstruction.

murmurQuiz.scenario: 6-month-old with holosystolic murmur at apex radiating to axilla. History of pharyngitis and fever 4 weeks ago. Carey-Coombs mid-diastolic rumble heard. Erythema marginatum rash on trunk.

parts.questionPrompt: What murmur is this?
parts.answer: Holosystolic murmur of Mitral Regurgitation (from acute rheumatic fever)
parts.explanation: MR from acute rheumatic fever produces a holosystolic murmur at the apex radiating to axilla. The Carey-Coombs murmur (soft mid-diastolic rumble) results from inflamed mitral leaflets. Erythema marginatum is pathognomonic for ARF.

parts.questionPrompt: What diagnostic criteria are used?
parts.answer: Jones criteria (2 major OR 1 major + 2 minor + evidence of prior GAS)
parts.explanation: Jones criteria Majors: Carditis, Polyarthritis, Chorea, Erythema marginatum, Subcutaneous nodules. Minors: fever, arthralgia, elevated ESR/CRP, prolonged PR. Must have evidence of prior GAS (throat culture, rapid strep, or elevated ASO/anti-DNase B).

parts.questionPrompt: How long should secondary prophylaxis continue?
parts.answer: 10 years or until age 21 (without carditis: 5 years); lifelong if persistent valve disease
distractors: Single dose of benzathine penicillin G
parts.explanation: Secondary prophylaxis with benzathine penicillin G (IM q3-4 weeks) prevents recurrence. No carditis = 5 years or age 21. Carditis without valve disease = 10 years or age 21. Persistent valve disease = 10 years or age 40+ (some say lifelong).

murmurQuiz.scenario: 8-year-old with high-pitched blowing early diastolic decrescendo murmur. Best heard at Erb's point sitting up leaning forward at end-expiration. Wide pulse pressure. Bounding 'water-hammer' pulses.

parts.questionPrompt: What murmur is this?
parts.answer: Early diastolic decrescendo murmur of Aortic Regurgitation
parts.explanation: AR produces a high-pitched, blowing, early diastolic DECRESCENDO murmur best heard at Erb's point (3rd LICS) with patient sitting up, leaning forward, at end-expiration. Wide pulse pressure and water-hammer pulses from diastolic runoff into LV.

parts.questionPrompt: What is the most common cause of AR in a child?
parts.answer: Acute rheumatic fever (valvulitis damaging the aortic valve)
parts.explanation: In pediatrics, ARF causing aortic valvulitis is the most common cause of AR. Other causes: bicuspid AV, endocarditis, Marfan (aortic root dilation), and connective tissue disorders. In adults, degenerative/calcific disease predominates.

murmurQuiz.scenario: Toddler with weak femoral pulses and strong brachial pulses. BP: right arm 130/85, right leg 80/60. Continuous murmur over left back/interscapular area. CXR: rib notching, figure-3 sign.

parts.questionPrompt: What murmur is this?
parts.answer: Systolic/continuous murmur of Coarctation of the Aorta
parts.explanation: CoA produces a systolic (or continuous) murmur heard over the left back from turbulent flow through the narrowed aortic segment. Upper/lower extremity BP gradient >20 mmHg is classic. Rib notching = dilated intercostal collaterals. Figure-3 = pre/post-stenotic dilation.

parts.questionPrompt: What syndrome is associated with coarctation, bicuspid AV, and webbed neck in a female?
parts.answer: Turner syndrome (45,X)
parts.explanation: Turner syndrome (45,X) is classically associated with CoA and bicuspid AV. Features: short stature, webbed neck, shield chest, lymphedema, streak gonads. Noonan syndrome = PS (affects all genders). Williams = supravalvular AS.

parts.questionPrompt: This neonate with critical CoA is becoming acidotic and tachypneic. Emergency treatment?
parts.answer: PGE1 (prostaglandin E1) to reopen the ductus arteriosus
parts.explanation: In neonatal critical CoA with shock, PGE1 reopens the ductus → blood bypasses the coarctation to perfuse the lower body. Indomethacin would WORSEN the situation. Definitive repair is surgical (resection and end-to-end anastomosis or subclavian flap repair).

murmurQuiz.scenario: 3-year-old with cyanosis since infancy. Now squatting during play. Systolic ejection murmur at LUSB that gets SOFTER during a crying spell. Boot-shaped heart on CXR with decreased pulmonary vascular markings.

parts.questionPrompt: What murmur is this and why does it get softer during the spell?
parts.answer: SEM of Tetralogy of Fallot — murmur softens because worsening RVOT obstruction reduces flow
distractors: VSD murmur that decreases from lower gradient
PDA murmur that decreases from ductal closure
Innocent murmur that varies with respiration
parts.explanation: ToF murmur = SEM from flow across stenotic RVOT. During a tet spell, RVOT obstruction INCREASES → less blood crosses → murmur SOFTENS/disappears → more R-to-L shunt through VSD → worse cyanosis. A softening murmur with worsening cyanosis = tet spell.

parts.questionPrompt: What is the immediate treatment of a tet spell?
parts.answer: Knee-to-chest positioning + oxygen + morphine + IV fluids
parts.explanation: Tet spell management: 1) Knee-to-chest (increases SVR → reduces R-to-L shunt). 2) O2. 3) IV morphine (reduces hyperpnea). 4) IV fluids (increase preload). 5) Phenylephrine if refractory (increases SVR). Long-term: propranolol until surgical repair (complete repair by 3-6 months).

parts.questionPrompt: This child has 22q11.2 deletion. What syndrome and other expected findings?
parts.answer: DiGeorge syndrome — thymic aplasia, hypocalcemia, cleft palate, abnormal facies
distractors: Down syndrome — AV canal, Brushfield spots
Williams syndrome — supravalvular AS, elfin facies
parts.explanation: 22q11.2 deletion = DiGeorge/velocardiofacial syndrome. CATCH-22: Cardiac (conotruncal: ToF, truncus, interrupted arch), Abnormal facies, Thymic aplasia (T-cell deficiency), Cleft palate, Hypocalcemia (absent parathyroids). Most common microdeletion syndrome.

murmurQuiz.scenario: Newborn with severe cyanosis within hours of birth. Cyanosis does NOT improve with supplemental oxygen. Single loud S2. NO murmur. CXR: 'egg-on-a-string' appearance, narrow mediastinum.

parts.questionPrompt: What is the diagnosis despite having NO murmur?
parts.answer: d-Transposition of the Great Arteries (parallel circulation, no turbulent flow)
parts.explanation: d-TGA often has NO murmur because the two circuits run in parallel (aorta from RV, PA from LV) without turbulent flow across a defect. Single loud S2 from anterior aorta. Cyanosis unresponsive to O2 = parallel circulation without adequate mixing.

parts.questionPrompt: What is the initial stabilization procedure?
parts.answer: PGE1 + balloon atrial septostomy (Rashkind procedure) to allow mixing
parts.explanation: PGE1 keeps the ductus open for some mixing. Balloon atrial septostomy (Rashkind procedure) creates/enlarges an ASD to allow oxygenated and deoxygenated blood to mix at the atrial level. Definitive: arterial switch operation (Jatene) within the first 2 weeks of life.

murmurQuiz.scenario: Child with holosystolic murmur at LLSB. Murmur increases with INSPIRATION. Prominent v waves in JVP. Pulsatile liver on exam.

parts.questionPrompt: What murmur is this?
parts.answer: Holosystolic murmur of Tricuspid Regurgitation (increases with inspiration = Carvallo sign)
parts.explanation: TR produces a holosystolic murmur at LLSB. Carvallo sign: increases with INSPIRATION (more venous return to RV → more regurgitant volume → louder). Prominent v waves in JVP and pulsatile liver = severe TR.

parts.questionPrompt: The patient also has WPW on ECG and massive cardiomegaly. What underlying anomaly?
parts.answer: Ebstein anomaly (apical displacement of tricuspid valve)
parts.explanation: Ebstein anomaly = apical displacement of tricuspid valve into RV → atrialized RV → severe TR. Classically associated with WPW (accessory pathway) and SVT. CXR: 'wall-to-wall' cardiomegaly. Associated with maternal lithium exposure.

murmurQuiz.scenario: 10-year-old with new holosystolic murmur and early diastolic murmur. Fever for 2 weeks, fatigue. Janeway lesions on palms, Osler nodes on fingertips, splinter hemorrhages. Positive blood cultures.

parts.questionPrompt: What is causing these new murmurs?
parts.answer: Infective endocarditis (valve destruction → new regurgitant murmurs)
parts.explanation: Endocarditis causes NEW murmurs from valve destruction — vegetations destroy leaflets → regurgitation. Holosystolic = MR/TR. Early diastolic = AR. Janeway lesions (painless, palms/soles) and Osler nodes (painful, fingertips) are classic embolic/immunologic phenomena.

parts.questionPrompt: What diagnostic criteria are used?
parts.answer: Modified Duke criteria (2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor)
parts.explanation: Duke criteria. Major: positive blood cultures (typical organisms in 2 cultures), endocardial involvement on echo (vegetation, abscess, new regurgitation). Minor: predisposing condition, fever, vascular phenomena (Janeway, emboli), immunologic (Osler nodes, Roth spots, RF), positive cultures not meeting major.

parts.questionPrompt: What is the most common organism causing endocarditis in children with congenital heart disease?
parts.answer: Streptococcus viridans (alpha-hemolytic strep)
parts.explanation: Strep viridans is the #1 cause of subacute endocarditis in children with underlying CHD. Staph aureus is #1 in acute endocarditis, IV drug users, and prosthetic valves. HACEK organisms (Haemophilus, Aggregatibacter, Cardiobacterium, Eikenella, Kingella) cause culture-negative endocarditis.

murmurQuiz.scenario: Soft systolic murmur heard in healthy newborn nursery. Murmur radiates to bilateral axillae and back. Disappears completely by 6-month well-child visit. Normal echo, normal O2 saturations.

parts.questionPrompt: What murmur is this?
parts.answer: Peripheral pulmonic stenosis (innocent newborn flow murmur)
parts.explanation: Peripheral pulmonic stenosis is an innocent newborn murmur caused by acute angle branching of the PAs. Radiates to axillae and back (where branch PAs are). Resolves by 3-6 months as PAs grow. No workup needed.

parts.questionPrompt: What feature would make you worry this is PATHOLOGIC rather than innocent?
parts.answer: Persistence beyond 6 months, associated cyanosis, or RV hypertrophy on ECG
distractors: Murmur heard in the first week of life
parts.explanation: Red flags for pathologic murmur: persistence > 6 months, cyanosis, RVH on ECG, failure to thrive, fixed split S2, diastolic component, or grade ≥3/6. Innocent murmurs are soft, systolic, vary with position, and the child is asymptomatic with normal growth.

murmurQuiz.scenario: Adolescent with continuous low-pitched murmur at right supraclavicular area. Disappears when patient turns head, lies down, or with light jugular vein compression. Asymptomatic.

parts.questionPrompt: What murmur is this?
parts.answer: Venous hum (innocent continuous murmur)
parts.explanation: Venous hum is a common innocent continuous murmur from turbulent flow in jugular veins. Heard at right supraclavicular area. KEY: disappears with head turning, supine position, or jugular compression. PDA does NOT disappear with these maneuvers.

parts.questionPrompt: How do you distinguish a venous hum from a PDA murmur?
parts.answer: Venous hum disappears with supine position/head turn/jugular compression; PDA does not
distractors: PDA is softer than venous hum
Venous hum has wide pulse pressure
PDA is only heard in neonates
parts.explanation: Both are continuous murmurs. Venous hum disappears with positional changes (interrupts jugular flow). PDA murmur persists regardless of position and has bounding pulses/wide pulse pressure. PDA is at left infraclavicular area; venous hum at supraclavicular area.

murmurQuiz.scenario: 5-year-old girl with fever >5 days, bilateral non-exudative conjunctivitis, strawberry tongue, polymorphous rash, edema of hands/feet. New cardiac murmur. Echo: coronary artery dilation (z-score 2.8).

parts.questionPrompt: What disease is causing this new murmur?
parts.answer: Kawasaki disease (medium-vessel vasculitis with coronary artery involvement)
parts.explanation: Kawasaki disease: fever ≥5 days + 4/5: conjunctivitis (bilateral, non-exudative), oral changes (strawberry tongue, cracked lips), rash (polymorphous), extremity changes (edema, desquamation), cervical lymphadenopathy. Coronary artery aneurysms are the major complication.

parts.questionPrompt: What is the treatment to prevent coronary complications?
parts.answer: IVIG (2 g/kg) + high-dose aspirin within 10 days of fever onset
parts.explanation: IVIG 2 g/kg single infusion + high-dose aspirin (80-100 mg/kg/day). Reduces coronary aneurysm risk from 25% to <5%. After fever resolves → low-dose aspirin (3-5 mg/kg/day) for 6-8 weeks. IVIG-resistant (~10-20%) may need repeat IVIG or infliximab.

parts.questionPrompt: What is the most feared long-term complication?
parts.answer: Coronary artery aneurysms → risk of thrombosis and myocardial infarction
parts.explanation: Coronary artery aneurysms (especially giant aneurysms >8mm) can thrombose → myocardial infarction and sudden death. Long-term aspirin and sometimes anticoagulation needed. Kawasaki is the #1 cause of acquired heart disease in developed countries in children.

murmurQuiz.scenario: 6-week-old with poor feeding and tachypnea. Prominent S3 gallop at apex. Soft holosystolic murmur at apex. CXR: pulmonary edema, cardiomegaly. Echo: dilated LV with EF 25%.

parts.questionPrompt: What is causing this holosystolic murmur?
parts.answer: Mitral regurgitation from dilated cardiomyopathy (annular dilation)
parts.explanation: DCM causes ventricular dilation → mitral annular dilation → MR → soft holosystolic murmur at apex. S3 gallop indicates rapid ventricular filling in a dilated, failing ventricle. The MR is functional (annular dilation), not structural (leaflet disease).

parts.questionPrompt: What is the most common cause of DCM in children?
parts.answer: Viral myocarditis (enterovirus, adenovirus most common)
parts.explanation: Viral myocarditis (especially enterovirus/Coxsackie B and adenovirus) is the #1 cause of DCM in children. Other causes: genetic/familial, metabolic (carnitine deficiency), Duchenne muscular dystrophy, chemotherapy (doxorubicin). Unlike adults, CAD and HTN are rare causes in peds.

murmurQuiz.scenario: Infant with Down syndrome. Holosystolic murmur at LLSB plus mid-diastolic rumble at apex. Echo shows complete atrioventricular canal defect (AVCD). Developing heart failure symptoms.

parts.questionPrompt: What murmurs are expected with a complete AV canal defect?
parts.answer: Holosystolic from VSD + MR/TR (regurgitation through common AV valve) + diastolic rumble from increased flow
parts.explanation: Complete AVCD (endocardial cushion defect) produces multiple murmurs: holosystolic from VSD component, holosystolic from MR/TR (common AV valve regurgitation), and mid-diastolic rumble from increased AV valve flow. ~40% of cardiac defects in Down syndrome are AVCD.

parts.questionPrompt: When should surgical repair be performed?
parts.answer: By 4-6 months of age (before irreversible pulmonary vascular disease)
parts.explanation: Complete AVCD with large L-to-R shunt causes early CHF and rapid pulmonary vascular disease progression — especially in Down syndrome (higher risk of early Eisenmenger). Surgical repair by 4-6 months prevents irreversible pulmonary hypertension.

murmurQuiz.scenario: A 4-month-old's VSD murmur is getting progressively SOFTER. The child is becoming MORE cyanotic with worsening tachypnea. Echo shows equalized ventricular pressures.

parts.questionPrompt: Why is the murmur getting softer despite worsening symptoms?
parts.answer: Eisenmenger progression — rising pulmonary vascular resistance equalizes pressures, eliminating the gradient
parts.explanation: RED FLAG: VSD murmur getting SOFTER + worsening cyanosis = Eisenmenger physiology. Chronic L-to-R shunt damages pulmonary vasculature → PVR rises → LV-RV gradient decreases → murmur softens → eventually R-to-L shunt (cyanosis). This is an indication for URGENT surgical repair.

parts.questionPrompt: What happens if surgical repair is delayed too long?
parts.answer: Irreversible pulmonary vascular disease (Eisenmenger syndrome) — surgery is then contraindicated
distractors: Compensatory RV hypertrophy resolves the issue
Shunt reversal is always reversible with surgery
parts.explanation: Once Eisenmenger syndrome is established (fixed elevated PVR with R-to-L shunt), surgical VSD closure is CONTRAINDICATED — removing the 'pop-off' valve would cause acute RV failure. Treatment at this stage is medical: pulmonary vasodilators (sildenafil, bosentan). Ultimately may need heart-lung transplant.

murmurQuiz.scenario: Newborn infant of a diabetic mother. Large for gestational age. Systolic murmur heard. Echo shows asymmetric septal hypertrophy with dynamic LVOT obstruction.

parts.questionPrompt: What murmur pattern would you expect?
parts.answer: Crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur similar to HOCM (dynamic LVOT obstruction)
parts.explanation: Infants of diabetic mothers (IDM) can develop transient hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with asymmetric septal hypertrophy causing dynamic LVOT obstruction — producing a systolic murmur identical to HOCM. This is transient and typically resolves within 2-4 months.

parts.questionPrompt: What is the management?
parts.answer: Supportive care — the septal hypertrophy is transient and resolves within months
parts.explanation: Unlike genetic HOCM, IDM hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is transient. The hypertrophy resolves as insulin levels normalize postnatally (typically 2-4 months). Avoid inotropes and volume depletion. If symptomatic, cautious beta-blocker use. No surgical intervention needed.

murmurQuiz.scenario: Infant with continuous murmur at upper left chest. Mother had rubella during first trimester. Child has cataracts and sensorineural hearing loss.

parts.questionPrompt: What cardiac lesion is most associated with congenital rubella?
parts.answer: PDA (most common cardiac defect in congenital rubella syndrome)
parts.explanation: Congenital rubella syndrome classically causes PDA and peripheral pulmonic stenosis. The triad: cataracts/glaucoma, sensorineural deafness, cardiac defects (PDA, peripheral PS). Also: blueberry muffin rash, microcephaly, intellectual disability.

parts.questionPrompt: What other cardiac lesion (besides PDA) is characteristic of congenital rubella?
parts.answer: Peripheral pulmonic stenosis (branch PA stenosis)
parts.explanation: Congenital rubella causes both PDA and peripheral (branch) pulmonary artery stenosis. The peripheral PS murmur radiates to the axillae and back, similar to the innocent peripheral PS of newborns but persists beyond 6 months.

murmurQuiz.scenario: 15-year-old competitive swimmer presents for sports physical. Systolic murmur heard. It INCREASES with Valsalva. She has no symptoms. Family history: uncle died suddenly at age 28 during a marathon.

parts.questionPrompt: The murmur increases with Valsalva. What is the most likely murmur?
parts.answer: HOCM murmur (dynamic LVOT obstruction)
parts.explanation: HOCM is the ONLY murmur that characteristically INCREASES with Valsalva. Decreased preload → smaller LV → more LVOT obstruction → louder murmur. Fixed AS, MR, and VSD all get SOFTER with Valsalva (less volume = less turbulence).

parts.questionPrompt: What is the inheritance pattern of HOCM?
parts.answer: Autosomal dominant (mutations in sarcomeric proteins — beta-myosin heavy chain most common)
parts.explanation: HOCM is autosomal dominant with variable penetrance. Most common mutations involve sarcomeric proteins (beta-myosin heavy chain, myosin-binding protein C). First-degree relatives should be screened with echo and ECG. Family history of sudden death is a major red flag.

parts.questionPrompt: She wants to continue competitive swimming. Your recommendation?
parts.answer: Disqualify from competitive sports — HOCM is the #1 cause of SCD in young athletes
parts.explanation: ALL competitive sports are contraindicated in HOCM regardless of symptoms. HOCM is the #1 cause of SCD in young athletes. Exercise triggers ventricular arrhythmias in the hypertrophied heart. Recreational low-intensity activity may be discussed on a case-by-case basis.

murmurQuiz.scenario: Teenage girl with normal exam develops a soft systolic murmur during pregnancy. Murmur was not present before pregnancy. No diastolic component, no symptoms. Normal echo.

parts.questionPrompt: What is the cause of this new murmur?
parts.answer: Physiologic flow murmur (pregnancy increases cardiac output by 30-50%)
parts.explanation: Pregnancy increases CO by 30-50% → can produce an innocent systolic flow murmur (grade 1-2, systolic, no diastolic component, normal S2). Resolves postpartum. Same concept applies to any high-output state (anemia, fever, thyrotoxicosis).

parts.questionPrompt: When should a murmur in pregnancy trigger concern?
parts.answer: Diastolic murmur — NEVER physiologic in pregnancy
distractors: Murmur heard in the third trimester
parts.explanation: A diastolic murmur in pregnancy is NEVER physiologic and warrants full evaluation (echo, cardiology referral). Systolic flow murmurs are common and usually benign. Other red flags: loud (≥3/6) murmur, symptoms (dyspnea at rest, syncope, chest pain), or known cardiac history.

murmurQuiz.scenario: Newborn with snowman sign (figure-8) on CXR. Mild cyanosis. Wide fixed split S2. Soft systolic ejection murmur at LUSB.

parts.questionPrompt: What congenital heart defect causes a 'snowman sign' on CXR?
parts.answer: Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Return (TAPVR) — supracardiac type
parts.explanation: Snowman (figure-8) sign is classic for supracardiac TAPVR — the dilated vertical vein and SVC form the 'head' of the snowman, and the heart is the 'body'. All pulmonary veins drain anomalously. Mixing occurs at an obligatory ASD/PFO. Fixed split S2 from RV volume overload.

parts.questionPrompt: What is the most critical presentation of TAPVR?
parts.answer: Obstructed TAPVR — presents with severe cyanosis, pulmonary edema, and hemodynamic collapse in the first days of life
parts.explanation: Obstructed TAPVR (especially infracardiac type, drainage below diaphragm through liver) is a surgical emergency. Pulmonary venous return is obstructed → severe pulmonary edema, cyanosis, and shock. CXR shows white-out lungs without cardiomegaly. Requires emergent surgical repair.

murmurQuiz.scenario: 7-year-old with a harsh systolic murmur. The murmur gets LOUDER when the child squats and SOFTER when standing. No click. Radiates to axilla.

parts.questionPrompt: Which murmur gets LOUDER with squatting?
parts.answer: Most murmurs (VSD, MR, AS) — squatting increases preload and afterload, increasing flow/gradient
parts.explanation: Squatting increases both preload (venous return) AND afterload (SVR) → increases flow volume and pressure gradients → MOST murmurs get LOUDER. The exceptions are HOCM (gets SOFTER — less obstruction) and MVP (click moves LATER, murmur shortens). This distinction is extremely high-yield.

parts.questionPrompt: Given that this murmur radiates to the axilla, where is the likely valve involved?
parts.answer: Mitral valve (MR radiates to axilla)
parts.explanation: Radiation to the axilla is characteristic of mitral regurgitation. AS radiates to carotids. TR and PS are right-sided and don't typically radiate to the axilla. The direction of radiation follows the jet of regurgitant/turbulent blood flow.

murmurQuiz.scenario: Asymptomatic 4-year-old found to have a murmur at well-child visit. Soft systolic murmur that changes with position. Normal S1 and S2. No diastolic sounds, no clicks. Normal growth and development.

parts.questionPrompt: Which features suggest this is an INNOCENT murmur?
parts.answer: All of the above — soft, systolic, position-dependent, normal S1/S2, no clicks, asymptomatic, normal growth
distractors: Only the absence of diastolic sounds
parts.explanation: Innocent murmur features (7 S's): Soft, Systolic, Short duration, Single (no extra sounds), Small (young child), Symptom-free, and Situation-dependent (changes with position/activity). ANY diastolic component, harsh quality, click, or symptoms should prompt evaluation.

parts.questionPrompt: Which finding would REQUIRE an echocardiogram?
parts.answer: Diastolic murmur
distractors: Murmur heard during a febrile illness
parts.explanation: Diastolic murmurs are ALWAYS pathologic and require echo. Other indications: harsh/loud (≥3/6), fixed split S2, abnormal S2, clicks, symptoms (syncope, cyanosis, FTT, exercise intolerance), or abnormal ECG/CXR. A systolic murmur louder when supine or during fever can be innocent.

murmurQuiz.scenario: Newborn with a single S2 (not split). Cyanosis present. Truncal arterial vessel overrides a large VSD on echo. Harsh systolic murmur at LLSB.

parts.questionPrompt: What congenital heart defect presents with a single S2 and a single truncal vessel?
parts.answer: Truncus arteriosus (single great vessel arising from heart with underlying VSD)
parts.explanation: Truncus arteriosus = single arterial trunk gives rise to both aorta and PA, arising from both ventricles over a large VSD. Single S2 because there is only one semilunar valve (truncal valve). Associated with 22q11.2 deletion (DiGeorge).

parts.questionPrompt: What genetic syndrome is most commonly associated?
parts.answer: DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion) — also associated with ToF and interrupted aortic arch
parts.explanation: 22q11.2 deletion causes conotruncal defects: truncus arteriosus, ToF, interrupted aortic arch, and VSD. CATCH-22 mnemonic. Truncus arteriosus has one of the strongest associations with DiGeorge. Always check calcium (hypocalcemia from absent parathyroids).

murmurQuiz.scenario: Premature infant with a PDA murmur. You start indomethacin. The PDA does not close after 3 courses of indomethacin.

parts.questionPrompt: Indomethacin has failed. What is the next step?
parts.answer: Surgical PDA ligation (or transcatheter device closure)
distractors: Observation and wait for spontaneous closure
parts.explanation: When pharmacologic closure fails (typically after 2-3 courses), surgical ligation or transcatheter device closure is indicated for hemodynamically significant PDA. Continued observation risks persistent heart failure and pulmonary overcirculation.

parts.questionPrompt: In which situations would you want to KEEP a PDA OPEN with PGE1?
parts.answer: Ductal-dependent lesions (d-TGA, critical CoA, critical PS, HLHS, pulmonary atresia)
parts.explanation: PGE1 keeps the ductus open when systemic or pulmonary circulation DEPENDS on it. Ductal-dependent systemic circulation: critical CoA, HLHS, interrupted aortic arch. Ductal-dependent pulmonary circulation: critical PS, pulmonary atresia, severe ToF. d-TGA needs mixing via PDA.

murmurQuiz.scenario: Newborn with murmur. Absent thymic shadow on CXR. Hypocalcemia causing seizures. Cleft palate noted on exam.

parts.questionPrompt: What syndrome and what type of cardiac defect is expected?
parts.answer: DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion) — conotruncal defects (ToF, truncus, interrupted aortic arch)
parts.explanation: CATCH-22: Cardiac (conotruncal defects), Abnormal facies, Thymic aplasia (absent thymic shadow → T-cell deficiency), Cleft palate, Hypocalcemia (absent/hypoplastic parathyroids → seizures). Most common microdeletion syndrome.

parts.questionPrompt: What immune deficiency results from thymic aplasia?
parts.answer: T-cell deficiency (impaired cell-mediated immunity)
parts.explanation: Absent thymus → deficient T-cell production → susceptibility to viral, fungal, and intracellular bacterial infections. Severity varies from partial (most common) to complete DiGeorge. Live vaccines are contraindicated in severe cases. Must check lymphocyte subsets.

murmurQuiz.scenario: Child presenting with migratory polyarthritis affecting large joints. Low-grade fever. Prolonged PR interval on ECG. History of untreated sore throat 3 weeks prior. No murmur initially, but carditis develops.

parts.questionPrompt: What valve is MOST commonly affected in acute rheumatic fever?
parts.answer: Mitral valve (causing MR — most common valvular lesion)
parts.explanation: The mitral valve is the most commonly affected valve in ARF. Acute phase: MR (holosystolic at apex). Chronic rheumatic heart disease: mitral STENOSIS (low-pitched diastolic rumble at apex). The aortic valve is the second most commonly affected.

parts.questionPrompt: What is the MOST common presentation of ARF?
parts.answer: Migratory polyarthritis (present in ~75% of cases)
parts.explanation: Migratory polyarthritis of large joints is the MOST common manifestation (~75%). Carditis (~50%) is the most serious. Chorea (Sydenham) can appear months after infection. Erythema marginatum and subcutaneous nodules are rare but highly specific.

murmurQuiz.scenario: 10-year-old with new murmur during a febrile illness. Previously well. The murmur is grade 2/6 systolic, heard at LLSB, disappears when the fever resolves. No other cardiac findings.

parts.questionPrompt: What is this murmur?
parts.answer: Fever-accentuated innocent flow murmur (high cardiac output state)
parts.explanation: Fever increases cardiac output → can unmask or accentuate an innocent flow murmur. Key features: disappears when fever resolves, soft grade, no diastolic component, no symptoms. Other high-output states causing this: anemia, anxiety, exercise, pregnancy, thyrotoxicosis.

parts.questionPrompt: What would make you suspect this murmur is NOT innocent?
parts.answer: Murmur persists after fever resolves, diastolic component present, or new symptoms develop
distractors: Murmur heard during first fever episode
parts.explanation: Red flags suggesting pathology: murmur persists after fever/illness resolves, diastolic component appears, new symptoms (exercise intolerance, syncope, chest pain), new cardiac findings (gallop, thrill, abnormal S2), or positive blood cultures (endocarditis).

murmurQuiz.scenario: A murmur is described as holosystolic, heard at LLSB, with NO change with respiration. Another murmur at the same location INCREASES with inspiration.

parts.questionPrompt: The murmur that does NOT change with respiration is most likely from which side of the heart?
parts.answer: Left-sided (VSD) — left-sided murmurs are NOT significantly affected by respiration
distractors: Neither — all murmurs change with respiration
parts.explanation: Left-sided murmurs (VSD, MR, AS, AR) are generally NOT affected by respiration because left heart filling is relatively constant. Right-sided murmurs (TR, PS, TS) change with respiration — they INCREASE with inspiration because inspiration increases venous return to the right heart.

parts.questionPrompt: The murmur that INCREASES with inspiration is most likely?
parts.answer: Tricuspid regurgitation (right-sided murmur — Carvallo sign positive)
parts.explanation: Carvallo sign: right-sided murmurs increase with inspiration. TR increases because inspiration → increased venous return to RV → more regurgitant volume. PS also increases with inspiration. This maneuver helps distinguish TR from VSD or MR at the LLSB.

murmurQuiz.scenario: Child with a history of Kawasaki disease treated 3 years ago. Now asymptomatic. Has mild coronary artery dilation persisting on echo.

parts.questionPrompt: What long-term surveillance is needed?
parts.answer: Serial echocardiograms + long-term low-dose aspirin + possible stress testing
parts.explanation: Persistent coronary changes require long-term cardiology follow-up with serial echo. Low-dose aspirin (antiplatelet) continues until aneurysms resolve. Giant aneurysms (>8mm) may need anticoagulation. Stress testing assesses for ischemia. Activity restrictions depend on aneurysm size.

parts.questionPrompt: What is Kawasaki disease the #1 cause of in developed countries?
parts.answer: Acquired heart disease in children
parts.explanation: Kawasaki disease has surpassed acute rheumatic fever as the #1 cause of acquired heart disease in children in developed countries. Coronary artery aneurysms and stenosis can lead to myocardial ischemia, infarction, and sudden death — even years after the acute illness.

murmurQuiz.scenario: Newborn with ductal-dependent cyanotic heart lesion. PGE1 is started. The nurse notices the baby becomes apneic.

parts.questionPrompt: What is the most important side effect of PGE1?
parts.answer: Apnea — be prepared to intubate when starting PGE1
parts.explanation: PGE1 side effects: APNEA (most important — always have intubation equipment ready), fever, hypotension, flushing, and diarrhea. Apnea occurs in ~12% of neonates receiving PGE1. Despite this risk, PGE1 is life-saving in ductal-dependent lesions.

parts.questionPrompt: Name 3 ductal-dependent lesions where PGE1 is essential.
parts.answer: Critical CoA, HLHS, d-TGA, pulmonary atresia, critical PS
parts.explanation: Ductal-dependent systemic flow: critical CoA, HLHS, interrupted aortic arch. Ductal-dependent pulmonary flow: critical PS, pulmonary atresia, severe ToF. Ductal-dependent mixing: d-TGA. These neonates will decompensate rapidly when the ductus closes (usually day 2-3 of life).

murmurQuiz.scenario: You are asked to differentiate two systolic murmurs on a shelf question. One is crescendo-decrescendo (diamond-shaped) and the other is holosystolic (plateau-shaped).

parts.questionPrompt: Which defects cause a CRESCENDO-DECRESCENDO (diamond/ejection) systolic murmur?
parts.answer: AS, PS, HOCM, ASD (flow murmur), ToF — all involve flow across a stenotic or obstructed valve/outflow
parts.explanation: Crescendo-decrescendo = ejection murmurs. Blood accelerates through stenosis, reaches peak velocity mid-systole, then decelerates. Causes: AS, PS, HOCM (dynamic obstruction), ASD (relative PS from increased flow), and ToF (RVOT obstruction). Innocent murmurs are also ejection-type.

parts.questionPrompt: Which defects cause a HOLOSYSTOLIC (plateau/pansystolic) murmur?
parts.answer: VSD, MR, TR — all involve regurgitation/shunting through a constant pressure gradient
parts.explanation: Holosystolic = regurgitant murmurs. The pressure gradient is constant throughout systole → uniform turbulence from S1 to S2. VSD (LV→RV shunt), MR (LV→LA regurgitation), TR (RV→RA regurgitation). The plateau shape distinguishes from the diamond shape of ejection murmurs.

murmurQuiz.scenario: 6-year-old with a continuous murmur. You need to determine if it is pathologic (PDA) or innocent (venous hum).

parts.questionPrompt: Where is a venous hum typically heard?
parts.answer: Right supraclavicular area (from turbulent flow in jugular veins)
parts.explanation: Venous hum is heard at the right (sometimes left) supraclavicular fossa from turbulent flow in the jugular veins. PDA murmur is at the LEFT INFRACLAVICULAR area (where the ductus is located). Location is the first clue to differentiation.

parts.questionPrompt: What bedside maneuver differentiates the two?
parts.answer: Venous hum disappears with supine position, head turning, or jugular compression; PDA persists
distractors: Venous hum gets louder with standing
parts.explanation: Venous hum: interrupted by anything that changes jugular venous flow (lying flat, turning head to compress JV, direct compression). PDA: continuous regardless of position because it's a fixed anatomic shunt. Also, PDA has bounding pulses/wide pulse pressure — venous hum does not.

murmurQuiz.scenario: Child with known bicuspid aortic valve. Currently asymptomatic with a grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at RUSB. Normal exercise tolerance.

parts.questionPrompt: What is the most important long-term risk of bicuspid AV?
parts.answer: Progressive aortic stenosis + risk of aortic root dilation and dissection
parts.explanation: Bicuspid AV (1-2% population, most common congenital cardiac anomaly) causes progressive AS over decades from turbulent flow → calcification. Also associated with aortic root dilation → risk of dissection (similar to Marfan). Requires serial echo monitoring even when asymptomatic.

parts.questionPrompt: What activity restriction is recommended?
parts.answer: Avoid heavy isometric exercise (weightlifting) if significant aortic root dilation, otherwise generally unrestricted
parts.explanation: Mild bicuspid AV without significant stenosis or aortic dilation → no activity restriction. If moderate-severe AS or significant aortic root dilation → avoid heavy isometric exercise (raises BP acutely → risk of dissection). Serial echo every 1-2 years monitors progression.

murmurQuiz.scenario: You are reviewing a child's echocardiogram. There is a large VSD with left-to-right shunt. The estimated PA pressure is 70% of systemic.

parts.questionPrompt: At what PA pressure ratio does irreversible pulmonary vascular disease become a concern?
parts.answer: When PA pressure exceeds 50-66% of systemic pressure — risk of Eisenmenger if not repaired
distractors: Only when PA pressure exceeds systemic
PA pressure is never clinically relevant
parts.explanation: When PA pressure is >50% of systemic, pulmonary vascular disease is progressing. Surgical repair should be performed BEFORE the PVR/SVR ratio exceeds 0.5 or the PA pressure exceeds 2/3 of systemic. Once Eisenmenger syndrome is established (fixed elevated PVR), surgical repair is contraindicated.

parts.questionPrompt: When should this VSD be repaired surgically?
parts.answer: Now — PA pressure at 70% of systemic indicates significant pulmonary hypertension requiring urgent repair
distractors: Wait until age 5 for elective repair
Repair only if PA pressure exceeds 100% of systemic
parts.explanation: PA pressure at 70% of systemic is an urgent indication for surgical repair to prevent irreversible Eisenmenger syndrome. Delay risks permanent pulmonary vascular disease. Post-repair, PA pressure typically normalizes if done before irreversible changes. The window for repair narrows with age.

acquiredHeartDisease.presentation: Fever ≥5 days + 4 of 5 criteria: bilateral conjunctivitis (non-purulent), oral changes (strawberry tongue, cracked lips), rash (polymorphous, non-vesicular), extremity changes (edema, erythema, desquamation), cervical lymphadenopathy (unilateral, 1.5+ cm)
acquiredHeartDisease.diagnostics: Echocardiography for coronary artery aneurysms/ectasia; elevated ESR/CRP, anemia, thrombocytosis (>450k), elevated transaminases
acquiredHeartDisease.treatment: IVIG (2 g/kg) + high-dose aspirin (80-100 mg/kg/day in 4 divided doses) started within 10 days of fever onset; then low-dose aspirin (3-5 mg/kg/day) for 6-8 weeks (or longer if coronary involvement)
acquiredHeartDisease.complications: Coronary artery aneurysms (25% untreated), myocarditis, pericarditis, myocardial infarction, sudden cardiac death
acquiredHeartDisease.pearlsForShelf: Most common cause of acquired heart disease in developed countries. INCOMPLETE Kawasaki disease: fever + <4 criteria but echo findings of coronary involvement. Recurrent Kawasaki disease occurs in <3%. Risk of IVIG resistance (10-20%) → need additional therapy

acquiredHeartDisease.presentation: Major Jones criteria (carditis, polyarthritis, chorea, erythema marginatum, subcutaneous nodules); minor criteria (fever, arthralgias, ESR/CRP elevated, prolonged PR interval on ECG); must have evidence of preceding Group A Strep infection
acquiredHeartDisease.diagnostics: Throat culture or rapid strep test (if recent), anti-Strep serology (ASO titer, anti-DNase B); ECG for PR prolongation; echo for valvulitis; elevated ESR/CRP
acquiredHeartDisease.treatment: Benzathine penicillin G 1.2 million units IM for acute infection (if positive strep); aspirin for acute carditis; corticosteroids if severe carditis; secondary prophylaxis (benzathine penicillin G monthly or daily penicillin V) to prevent recurrence
acquiredHeartDisease.complications: Rheumatic mitral stenosis (most common), aortic regurgitation, pancarditis, permanent valve damage
acquiredHeartDisease.pearlsForShelf: Jones criteria: need major + minor for initial ARF diagnosis; for recurrent ARF, need 2 major OR 1 major + 2 minor. Chorea (Sydenham chorea) can occur months after strep infection. Erythema marginatum is pathognomonic. Secondary prophylaxis continues at least 5 years (or until age 21, or longer if carditis)

acquiredHeartDisease.presentation: Viral prodrome → chest pain, dyspnea, palpitations, syncope; signs of heart failure (tachycardia, hepatomegaly, pulmonary edema)
acquiredHeartDisease.diagnostics: Elevated troponin I/T, BNP; ECG shows diffuse ST elevation (unlike MI which is localized), PR depression, T wave changes; echo shows reduced EF; cardiac MRI can show myocardial inflammation/edema
acquiredHeartDisease.treatment: Supportive care; ACE inhibitors, beta-blockers, diuretics for heart failure; IVIG for fulminant myocarditis; mechanical support if cardiogenic shock; avoid NSAIDs (may worsen inflammation)
acquiredHeartDisease.complications: Fulminant myocarditis with cardiogenic shock, sudden cardiac death, dilated cardiomyopathy, arrhythmias
acquiredHeartDisease.pearlsForShelf: Most common cause of myocarditis in children is viral (enterovirus, adenovirus, EBV). Can mimic MI but coronary angiography is normal. Fulminant myocarditis has worse prognosis but may recover better than acute myocarditis. Consider cardiac transplantation if refractory.

acquiredHeartDisease.presentation: Sharp pleuritic chest pain that improves with sitting forward; may have pericardial friction rub; signs of pericardial effusion (muffled heart sounds, pulsus paradoxus)
acquiredHeartDisease.diagnostics: Friction rub on auscultation; ECG shows diffuse ST elevation + PR depression (stage 1), then diffuse T wave inversion (stage 2); echo for pericardial effusion; elevated inflammatory markers
acquiredHeartDisease.treatment: NSAIDs (indomethacin, ibuprofen) + colchicine for viral pericarditis; corticosteroids if severe or recurrent; antibiotics if bacterial; pericardiocentesis if tamponade
acquiredHeartDisease.complications: Pericardial effusion, tamponade, constrictive pericarditis (rarely), arrhythmias
acquiredHeartDisease.pearlsForShelf: Viral pericarditis most common in children. Tuberculous pericarditis in endemic areas or immunocompromised. Bacterial pericarditis is medical emergency. Pulsus paradoxus >10 mmHg suggests tamponade.

acquiredHeartDisease.presentation: Fever, new or changing murmur, splenomegaly; Duke criteria: major (positive blood cultures, new regurgitation on echo) + minor (fever, vascular phenomena, immunologic phenomena, microbiological evidence)
acquiredHeartDisease.diagnostics: Blood cultures (3 sets before antibiotics); echo for vegetations, valve regurgitation, perivalvular abscesses; elevated ESR/CRP, anemia, hematuria
acquiredHeartDisease.treatment: IV antibiotics for 4-6 weeks based on organism and sensitivities; surgical intervention if large vegetations (>10 mm), embolism, hemodynamic compromise, or prosthetic valve
acquiredHeartDisease.complications: Septic emboli (brain, lungs, kidney), valve destruction, heart failure, conduction abnormalities, sepsis
acquiredHeartDisease.pearlsForShelf: Risk factors: congenital heart disease (especially cyanotic), VSD, PDA, prosthetic valve. Streptococcus viridans most common in children. Staphylococcus aureus common in IV drug users. Janeway lesions and Osler nodes are classic (but rare). Roth spots on fundus. Splinter hemorrhages under nails.

acquiredHeartDisease.presentation: Dyspnea, failure to thrive, fatigue, exercise intolerance; signs of heart failure (tachycardia, hepatomegaly, pulmonary edema, S3 gallop)
acquiredHeartDisease.diagnostics: Echo shows dilated ventricles with reduced EF (<40%); ECG shows nonspecific changes; elevated troponin, BNP; cardiac MRI for assessment
acquiredHeartDisease.treatment: ACE inhibitors, beta-blockers, diuretics, aldosterone antagonists; treat underlying cause if identified; consider device therapy (pacemaker, ICD, CRT) or transplantation if severe
acquiredHeartDisease.complications: Heart failure, arrhythmias, sudden cardiac death, thromboembolic events, cardiogenic shock
acquiredHeartDisease.pearlsForShelf: Causes in children: myocarditis (viral most common), muscular dystrophies (Duchenne), metabolic disorders, medications (chemotherapy, doxorubicin), infiltrative disease. Peripartum cardiomyopathy in adolescent females. Poor prognosis; many require transplantation.

acquiredHeartDisease.presentation: Asymptomatic or dyspnea, syncope, chest pain, palpitations with exertion; systolic murmur that increases with Valsalva/decreases with squatting
acquiredHeartDisease.diagnostics: Echo shows LV hypertrophy (asymmetric in HCM), SAM (systolic anterior motion of mitral valve), LVOT obstruction; ECG shows LVH, deep Q waves, T wave inversion; cardiac MRI shows HCM pattern
acquiredHeartDisease.treatment: Beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers (disopyramide for additional negative inotrope); disqualification from competitive sports; ICD if high-risk for sudden death (family history of SCD, syncope, massive LVH)
acquiredHeartDisease.complications: Sudden cardiac death (most common cause in young athletes), syncope, arrhythmias, atrial fibrillation, stroke, heart failure
acquiredHeartDisease.pearlsForShelf: Autosomal dominant inheritance (mutation in sarcomeric proteins). Screening: family history, ECG, echo. Most common cause of SCD in young athletes. Murmur increases with Valsalva (opposite to fixed AS). Avoid diuretics (decrease LV volume → increase obstruction).

acquiredHeartDisease.presentation: Dyspnea, fatigue, hepatomegaly, peripheral edema; diastolic dysfunction with normal to slightly reduced EF
acquiredHeartDisease.diagnostics: Echo shows normal LV size with restrictive pattern (biatrial enlargement); Doppler shows restrictive LV filling; cardiac MRI for characterization
acquiredHeartDisease.treatment: Diuretics for volume management; avoid beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors (worsen diastolic dysfunction); treat underlying cause if identifiable
acquiredHeartDisease.complications: Heart failure, arrhythmias, atrial fibrillation, thromboembolic events, sudden cardiac death
acquiredHeartDisease.pearlsForShelf: Causes: amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, malignancy, infiltrative disease. Rare in pediatrics but important to recognize. Poor prognosis; many require transplantation. Elevated BNP and restrictive pattern on echo differentiate from constrictive pericarditis.

acquiredHeartDisease.presentation: Often asymptomatic, discovered on prenatal echo or incidentally; may have arrhythmias, obstructive symptoms if large
acquiredHeartDisease.diagnostics: Echo shows mass, often multiple, benign appearance; cardiac MRI for characterization; associated with tuberous sclerosis in 50-80% of cases
acquiredHeartDisease.treatment: Observation if asymptomatic; surgical resection if obstructive, arrhythmogenic, or hemodynamically significant
acquiredHeartDisease.complications: LVOT/RVOT obstruction, arrhythmias, sudden cardiac death (rare), regression over time
acquiredHeartDisease.pearlsForShelf: Most common cardiac tumor in children. Rhabdomyoma associated with tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC1/TSC2 mutations). Many regress spontaneously. Check for TSC manifestations: skin lesions, seizures, renal angiomyolipomas.

acquiredHeartDisease.presentation: Sudden collapse during sports after blunt blow to chest (baseball, hockey, lacrosse); immediate loss of consciousness, ventricular fibrillation
acquiredHeartDisease.diagnostics: Clinical history of traumatic chest blow preceding sudden collapse; ECG shows VF; history of survival with successful resuscitation suggests commotio cordis
acquiredHeartDisease.treatment: Immediate CPR and defibrillation; supportive care; implantable cardioverter-defibrillator consideration if recurrent events
acquiredHeartDisease.complications: Sudden cardiac death, survival with neurologic sequelae if delayed CPR
acquiredHeartDisease.pearlsForShelf: Occurs with relatively low-force blow to chest during vulnerable window (ascending phase of T wave); mechanism is electrical instability, not structural injury. Rare but catastrophic. Prevention: chest protective gear in sports.

acquiredHeartDisease.presentation: Maternal SLE or Sjogren syndrome; infant presents with congenital heart block (third-degree), bradycardia, or cardiomyopathy; may have neonatal rash
acquiredHeartDisease.diagnostics: Maternal anti-Ro/SSA and/or anti-La/SSB serology; fetal/neonatal echo shows AV block; ECG confirms complete heart block
acquiredHeartDisease.treatment: Maternal corticosteroids during pregnancy to prevent progression; neonatal pacemaker placement if symptomatic heart block; supportive care
acquiredHeartDisease.complications: Complete heart block requiring pacemaker, myocarditis, heart failure, intrauterine fetal death if severe
acquiredHeartDisease.pearlsForShelf: Anti-Ro/SSA antibodies cross placenta and damage AV node. Risk 1-2% in maternal anti-Ro/SSA positive pregnancies; if previous child affected, risk increases to 15-20%. Diagnosis often made prenatally on fetal echo.

acquiredHeartDisease.presentation: Syncope with exertion, auditory stimuli (Jervell and Lange-Nielsen), or at rest; family history of syncope/sudden death; may be asymptomatic
acquiredHeartDisease.diagnostics: ECG shows prolonged QTc (>460 ms in males, >470 ms in females); genetic testing identifies mutations; stress test and Holter monitoring for arrhythmias
acquiredHeartDisease.treatment: Beta-blockers (propranolol, atenolol) as first-line; genetic counseling; ICD placement if high-risk or recurrent syncope despite beta-blockers; avoid QT-prolonging drugs
acquiredHeartDisease.complications: Syncope, sudden cardiac death (especially during adrenergic surges), torsades de pointes, risk with fever or ototoxic medications
acquiredHeartDisease.pearlsForShelf: Romano-Ward syndrome (autosomal dominant) accounts for 90% of LQTS. Jervell and Lange-Nielsen (autosomal recessive) includes congenital deafness. Trigger depends on genotype: LQT1/2 during exertion/emotion, LQT3 at rest/sleep. Avoid QT-prolonging drugs (macrolides, antiemetics, antipsychotics).

ecgPatterns.pattern: Right Axis Deviation (RAD) with Right Ventricular Hypertrophy (RVH)
ecgPatterns.description: QRS axis >+120°, tall R waves in V1 (>0.5 mV), deep S in V6, right atrial enlargement (tall P waves)
ecgPatterns.pedsNote: Normal in neonates and young infants (RV dominant at birth due to pulmonary vascular resistance). Gradual leftward axis shift occurs with age. RAD pathologic if persists beyond 6 months.
ecgPatterns.shelfTrap: Don't confuse physiologic RVH in newborns with pathologic RVH. Neonatal RAD with tall R in V1 is normal; RAD in toddler requires investigation.

ecgPatterns.pattern: Left Axis Deviation (LAD) with Left Ventricular Hypertrophy (LVH)
ecgPatterns.description: QRS axis <-30°, tall R waves in aVL and V5-6, deep S in III and aVF, increased voltage (Sokolow-Lyon index)
ecgPatterns.pedsNote: LAD unusual in children; suggests significant LV pressure or volume overload. May see LV strain pattern (T wave inversion in lateral leads).
ecgPatterns.shelfTrap: LAD in a child warrants cardiac evaluation for hypertension or structural disease. Don't dismiss as normal variant.

ecgPatterns.description: Heart rate typically 220-300 bpm in infants, 150-220 bpm in older children; narrow QRS (<0.09 sec); P waves often buried in T wave or after QRS
ecgPatterns.pedsNote: Most common tachyarrhythmia in infants. WPW associated with Ebstein anomaly. Adenosine IV is first-line treatment to terminate SVT.
ecgPatterns.shelfTrap: Narrow complex tachycardia in a young infant = think WPW/SVT. Adenosine will break AV nodal-dependent SVT; if not effective, consider atrial tachycardia.

ecgPatterns.description: Short PR interval (<0.12 sec), delta wave (slurred upstroke of QRS), wide QRS during sinus rhythm
ecgPatterns.pedsNote: Accessory pathway conducts impulse from atrium to ventricle, bypassing AV node. Risk of sudden cardiac death due to rapid conduction during atrial fibrillation. Restrict from sports.
ecgPatterns.shelfTrap: WPW found on routine ECG + history of palpitations = needs cardiac evaluation. Do NOT give AV nodal blockers (verapamil, digoxin) as monotherapy; use flecainide or amiodarone instead.

ecgPatterns.description: QTc >460 ms (males) or >470 ms (females); normal QTc <440 ms in children
associations: Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome (autosomal recessive with deafness)
ecgPatterns.pedsNote: Risk of syncope and torsades de pointes with exercise, emotion, or auditory startle. Beta-blockers first-line. Genetic testing identifies mutation.
ecgPatterns.shelfTrap: Prolonged QT + syncope = LQTS until proven otherwise. Avoid QT-prolonging drugs (macrolides, antipsychotics, antiemetics). ICD for high-risk patients.

ecgPatterns.description: PR interval prolonged (>0.20 sec in older children, >0.15 sec in infants) but each P wave followed by QRS
ecgPatterns.pedsNote: Benign in many cases, especially in athletes. No hemodynamic consequences. PR prolongation increases with age normally.
ecgPatterns.shelfTrap: First-degree block alone is usually benign. Look for clinical context (myocarditis, fever, recent URI) before worrying.

ecgPatterns.pattern: Heart Block - Second-Degree AV Block (Mobitz II)
ecgPatterns.description: Periodic dropped QRS; PR interval constant in conducted beats; His bundle involved
ecgPatterns.pedsNote: More serious than Mobitz I; risk of progression to third-degree block. May require pacemaker.
ecgPatterns.shelfTrap: Mobitz II requires urgent evaluation. Differentiate from Mobitz I (gradual PR prolongation before dropped beat) by constant PR in conducted beats.

ecgPatterns.description: No relationship between P waves and QRS; P waves march through QRS independently; slow junctional or ventricular escape rhythm
ecgPatterns.pedsNote: Congenital third-degree block often well-tolerated (escape rate usually 40-60 bpm); acquired third-degree block more symptomatic. Requires pacemaker.
ecgPatterns.shelfTrap: Neonatal third-degree block + maternal SLE/Sjogren = maternal anti-Ro/SSA antibodies. Bradycardia in newborn with cyanosis = consider heart block.

ecgPatterns.description: RAD (axis +60 to +160°), tall R in V1, deep S in V6, dominant RV, small/inverted T in V1-V2 (normal)
ecgPatterns.pedsNote: RV dominance is physiologic in neonates due to pulmonary vascular resistance from fetal life. Gradual shift to LV dominance by 6-12 months.
ecgPatterns.shelfTrap: Don't misread normal neonatal RAD as pathology. Axis gradually shifts leftward with age. By 6 months, should see shift toward normal axis.

ecgPatterns.description: Sawtooth flutter waves (F waves) at rate ~300 bpm (atrial rate), ventricular rate varies (often 150 if 2:1 conduction)
associations: Structural heart disease (ASD, VSD, Tetralogy of Fallot after repair)
ecgPatterns.pedsNote: Less common than SVT in infants but important to recognize. Often seen post-operatively after cardiac surgery.
ecgPatterns.shelfTrap: Atrial flutter is organized; treat with rate control or antiarrhythmics. If hemodynamically unstable → synchronized cardioversion.

ecgPatterns.description: Wide QRS tachycardia (>0.09 sec), AV dissociation (P waves marching through QRS), fusion beats, concordance
ecgPatterns.pedsNote: Rare in structurally normal hearts in children. Always indicates serious pathology. Requires urgent evaluation and treatment (amiodarone, cardioversion).
ecgPatterns.shelfTrap: Wide complex tachycardia in a child = assume VT until proven otherwise. Hemodynamically unstable VT requires immediate synchronized cardioversion.

ecgPatterns.description: Peaked T waves (tented appearance), wide QRS (>0.12 sec), peaked P waves, PR prolongation, ST depression, eventual sine-wave pattern
ecgPatterns.pedsNote: Peaked T waves are early sign; progression to sine wave indicates severe hyperkalemia with imminent cardiac arrest. Treat emergently with calcium gluconate.
ecgPatterns.shelfTrap: Peaked T waves on ECG = check potassium stat. Do not wait for clinical symptoms; ECG changes precede symptomatic hyperkalemia.

pharmacology.mechanism: Maintains patency of ductus arteriosus by preventing constriction of ductal smooth muscle
pharmacology.indication: Ductal-dependent cyanotic CHD (d-TGA, Tetralogy of Fallot, pulmonary atresia, critical coarctation, pulmonary stenosis, tricuspid atresia), ductal-dependent systemic lesions (interrupted aortic arch, critical coarctation, hypoplastic left heart)
pharmacology.pedsSpecific: Given IV; must have intubation supplies at bedside due to high risk of apnea. Dosing: 0.1 mcg/kg/min, titrate to desired effect. Maintain body temperature.
pharmacology.shelfPearl: If cyanotic newborn does NOT improve with 100% O2 → think ductal-dependent lesion → start PGE1. Egg-on-string + single loud S2 + cyanosis = d-TGA, needs PGE1 + balloon septostomy.

pharmacology.mechanism: Inhibits prostaglandin synthesis → promotes ductal closure
pharmacology.indication: Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) in premature infants; alternative to surgical ligation
sideEffects: Oliguria, acute kidney injury (renal vasodilation effect reversed)
pharmacology.pedsSpecific: Dosing: 0.1 mg/kg IV every 12-24 hours for 3 doses. Contraindicated if: active sepsis, thrombocytopenia <50k, bleeding, necrotizing enterocolitis. Monitor urine output and renal function.
pharmacology.shelfPearl: Most common pharmacologic closure agent for PDA in premature infants. Success rate ~70-80%. If fails, or contraindicated → surgical ligation. Ibuprofen alternative with similar efficacy, potentially fewer renal effects.

pharmacology.mechanism: Inhibits prostaglandin synthesis → promotes ductal closure (alternative to indomethacin)
pharmacology.indication: PDA closure in premature infants; similar efficacy to indomethacin with possibly fewer renal complications
pharmacology.pedsSpecific: Dosing: 10 mg/kg initial, then 5 mg/kg at 24 and 48 hours. Preferred over indomethacin in some settings due to better renal safety profile.
pharmacology.shelfPearl: Ibuprofen vs indomethacin: roughly equivalent efficacy; ibuprofen may have fewer renal side effects, making it preferred in some premature infants with borderline renal function.

pharmacology.mechanism: Positive inotrope (increases contractility) via Na+/K+-ATPase inhibition; also slows AV nodal conduction (negative chronotrope)
pharmacology.indication: Heart failure in infants/young children; SVT (slows AV nodal conduction); atrial fibrillation rate control
sideEffects: Digoxin toxicity: nausea, vomiting, arrhythmias (PVCs, bigeminy, AV block), visual disturbances
pharmacology.pedsSpecific: Narrow therapeutic window; requires careful dosing and monitoring. Loading dose varies by age/weight. Infants have increased digoxin sensitivity (increased Na+/K+-ATPase). Monitor for toxicity.
pharmacology.shelfPearl: Digoxin loading followed by maintenance dosing. Hypokalemia increases toxicity risk. Used less commonly now (replaced by ACE-I and beta-blockers in heart failure), but still important for SVT in infants. Digoxin toxicity with hypokalemia → dangerous.
